newsitem.title: THAILAND: Thai interbank market unquoted after baht float.
newsitem.headline: Thai interbank market unquoted after baht float.

text.p: Thai overnight interbank rates were unquoted on Wednesday morning after the baht was alllowed to float, dealers said.
Banks were unwilling to lend following the baht adjustment and were waiting for developments before they resumed lending.

"The interbank rate is not even being quoted. The only interday financing we are offering is to our corporate customers and that is on a case by case basis," said a dealer at a local bank. "I think we should get a clearer picture of where we want to be after the central bank sets the reference rate tonight."

The Bank of Thailand said it would set a reference rate for the baht based on a average of previous day trades. The baht was previously allowed to trade in a narrow range and pegged to a basket of currencies dominated by the U.S dollar.
"We have advised our clients that if they can avoid doing anything today then waiting would be better because it's going to very expensive," said another local dealer.
"No one in the market is lending this morning. I mean we have to say something but it's a figure we are setting ourselves, something over 20 percent," said a dealer at medium-sized bank.
The baht was trading between around 27.00/29.00 per dollar by 0400 GMT from 25.80/25.90 on Monday when the currency was pegged. The market was closed on Tuesday for a holiday.
Offshore the baht was trading at 27.00/29.00 per dollar against 24.80/25.20 on Monday.
The Bank of Thailand has pledged to maintain currency controls which had cut off baht supply to offshore speculators.
"I think it will probably end up at somewhere around 30 but it's just so volatile it's hard to say," said one local dealer.
Traders said they were surprised by the timing of the float.
"I'm absolutely speechless," the local dealer said.
